head.title: A Polemic Ripped From Today's Headlines

hedline.hl1: A Polemic Ripped From Today's Headlines

block.p: Current events play into the hands of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Fidelio.'' Gone is the tatty eyesore that limped regularly on and off the Met's stage. In its place, Jurgen Flimm's grim update of prison walls, cellblocks and civil unrest: stage pictures that would fit credibly on the screens of television news.

Beethoven's awkward, deeply moving attempt at opera seemed especially appropriate at Friday's first performance. Florestan, its hero, and Leonore, its heroine, battled judicial wickedness dressed not in tights but three-piece suits and combat fatigues. The Glock replaced the dagger as sidearm of choice; spears became shotguns. National identities are coyly anonymous in Florence von Gerkan's costumes, with khakis and billed caps that would fit most of the world's armies and police forces. Mr. Flimm's prison yard, with its high gray walls and junk-filled basement, might sit on the outskirts of Kuala Lumpur, Jerusalem, Lima or places closer to home.

Mr. Flimm's prison yard, with its high gray walls and junk-filled basement, might sit on the outskirts of Kuala Lumpur, Jerusalem, Lima or places closer to home.

The creator of last summer's ''Ring'' at the Bayreuth Festival is once again a practical man of the theater, not a maker of manifestoes. Scenes are made to look familiar to us right now; the need for suspensions of disbelief is at a minimum. Besotted by the American and French Revolutions and their noble possibilities, Beethoven made ''Fidelio'' a manifesto in itself, giving his opera an earnestness and passion that almost smothers it in good will.

Here is great music driven by heartfelt sentiment, struggling to occupy an operatic stage. The paradox is in ensembles and set pieces that are musical masterpieces and acute studies of human nature awkwardly aligned to the flow of events on the stage. Great moments either bump into each other or sit uncomfortably apart.

In Act II a powerful tenor aria rushes past a narrative void and collides with a choral finale that comes as close to mass hysteria as a great composer will allow. There is not enough space to recover from the first and prepare for the second. The domestic scenes of Act I, including a quartet and trio of extraordinary beauty and intimacy, never join fluently with the martial hubbub around them. Obsessive, half-mad, like a collection of small architectural masterpieces set in a chaotic city plan, ''Fidelio'' lurches magnificently.

Mr. Flimm is attentive to human interchanges and competent in the maneuvering of crowds. Most elements of Beethoven's world have been credibly brought up to date. His production also, and I think unwisely, buys into the composer's excesses, namely a childlike highmindedness pretty much at odds with the more cynical world in which the Met finds itself.
Beethoven's final roar of triumph and thanksgiving is frenzy without shame, and I wish Mr. Flimm had not so underlined its wild-eyed innocence with kneeling principals and semaphoric arm gestures.

He is fortunate in his cast. Karita Mattila is a Leonora of astonishing force and concentration, qualities achieved at no loss of vocal beauty. As Florestan, Ben Heppner brings considerable grace to one of opera's most trying tenor roles. Rene Pape (Rocco) and Jennifer Welch-Babidge (Marzelline) were both elegance itself.

Falk Struckmann's Pizarro forced and blustered in a way not all that inappropriate to the part. James Levine, known as a lover of orchestral beauty, met the sheer toughness of Beethoven's writing head on. The Met chorus, pushed to its limit, responded gloriously.

Few of us are sorry to see the Met's old ''Fidelio'' go. Shabby and dated both in outlook and physical condition, it gave this problem opera little chance to overcome its problems. Is Mr. Flimm's new version a burst of excitement? No. But like his Wagner at Bayreuth last summer it makes sense to our eyes and ears and lets Beethoven's tortured dramaturgy do the best it can.
Mr. Flimm also has Ms. Mattila, whose ''Abscheulicher! wo eilst du hin'' near the end of Act I was enough to send even the Met's staid audience rushing toward the barricades.

Opera in two acts by Ludwig van Beethoven, libretto by Joseph von Sonnleithner after the drama ''Leonore'' by Jean-Nicolas Bouilly; James Levine, conductor; production by Jurgen Flimm; sets by Robert Israel; costumes by Florence von Gerkan; lighting by Duane Schuler. At the Metropolitan Opera.

WITH: Karita Mattila (Leonore), Jennifer Welch-Babidge (Marzelline), Ben Heppner (Florestan), Matthew Polenzani (Jaquino), Falk Struckmann (Don Pizarro), Rene Pape (Rocco), Robert Lloyd (Don Fernando), Eric Cutler (First Prisoner) and Alfred Walker (Second Prisoner).
